evidence_span: Samples of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } – 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ and Zircaloy2 were prefilmed in steam $\mathbf { ( H _ { 2 } O }$ , $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ at ${\sim } 2 \ \mathbf { M P a } $ and subsequently exposed to ${ \bf D } _ { 2 } { \bf O }$ $1 0 ^ { - 3 }$ Pa to ${\sim } 1 8 \ \mathbf { M P a } ,$ and $\mathbf { D } _ { 2 }$ ${ \bf ( \sim } 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \ P a )$ at a temperature range of 250 to $3 8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$
conditions: prefilming: 400°C, ~2 MPa steam; exposure: D₂O (10⁻³ to ~18 MPa) and D₂ (~10⁻³ Pa), 250-380°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens were cut (typically ${ \sim } 1 0$ by 10 by $1 \ \mathrm { m m } )$ from cold-worked $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ and Zircaloy-2 CANDU pressure tubes and offcuts. The samples were machined and oxides were grown by steam autoclaving in light water $\mathbf { ( H _ { 2 } O ) }$ at ${ \sim } 2 \ \mathbf { M P a }$ and $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 2 4 \mathbf { h } }$ to reproduce the as-received pressure tubes condition.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk2
evidence_span: Experiment Number 1: D2 (gas) (filament on), Partial Pressure: 1.33 Pa, Temperature: 330°C, Exposure Duration: 60 min, Near Surface Concentration: 32 ppm
conditions: D2 gas, 1.33 Pa, 330°C, 60 min, filament on

evidence_span: Experiment Number 4: D_ (gas), Partial Pressure: 1064 Pa, Temperature: 350°C, Exposure Duration: 60 min, Near Surface Concentration: 19 ppm

evidence_span: Experiment Number 5: DO (vapor), Partial Pressure: 798 Pa, Temperature: 330°C, Exposure Duration: 34 min, Near Surface Concentration: 350 ppm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: Oxides on Zr-2.5Nb were exposed to ~10⁻³ Pa of D₂O for 1, 2, 4, 48, and 164 h

extra_properties.deuterium_concentration: 0.0097, 0.026, and 0.076 wt% at 0.02 μm depth for 1, 2, and 4 h exposures respectively

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The sample exposed to D₂O for 2h was subsequently exposed to vacuum (~1×10⁻⁵ Pa) at 300°C for 12h
process_step: exposed to D₂O vapor then vacuum

extra_properties.bonding_strength: relatively strong bonding of deuterium-containing species

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: exposing steam-prefilmed samples (in H₂O at 400°C for 48h) to a stream of argon bubbled through D₂O at 300°C for 168h

extra_properties.isotope_exchange: complete replacement of hydrogen by deuterium

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Deuterium and hydrogen through-oxide-thickness profiles after exposure to a stream of argon bubbled through $D _ { 2 } O$ at $3 0 0 ^ { \circ } C$ for 168 h. The samples were prefilmed by steam autoclaving at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } C$ for $\mathbf { 4 8 \ : h } .$
test_type: exposure to argon bubbled through D₂O

extra_properties.grain_size: columnar grains 20-50 nm wide, 200-500 nm long

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Deuterium through-oxide-thickness depth profiles resulting from out-reactor aqueous exposures to $_ { D _ { 2 } O }$ in autoclaves at $2 5 0 ^ { \circ }$ to $3 6 0 ^ { \circ } C$ for up to 600 days.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Typical deuterium profiles in inside surface oxides of $\mathbf { Z r } \mathbf { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ pressure tubes removed from operating reactors after up to 12 years operation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Outside surface oxides in removed pressure tubes were also examined. These had been exposed to reactor gas annuli $( \mathbf { N } _ { 2 }$ or $\mathbf { C O } _ { 2 } )$ at ${ \sim } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ with ${ \bf D } _ { 2 } { \bf O }$ partial pressures ranging from ${ \sim } 0 . 2 5$ to ${ \sim } 2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { P a }$ and $\mathbf { D } _ { 2 }$ partial pressures between ${ \sim } 1 0$ and $1 0 0 \ \mathbf { P a }$ for up to 13 years.
conditions: ~300°C, D₂O partial pressure 0.25-200 Pa, D₂ partial pressure 10-100 Pa, up to 13 years

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: TEM micrographs of a typical thin oxide formed on $Z r { - } 2 . 5 N b$ in steam showing (a) columnar grains extending to the outer surface of the oxide, and (b) niobiumrich band crossing the columnar grains and no apparent interconnected pores.

extra_properties.grain_size: columnar grains 20-50 nm wide, 200-500 nm long

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Inferred percentage hydrogen uptake in Zr-2.5Nb samples exposed out-reactor to aqueous D₂O at 250, 310, and 360°C, and from removed pressure tubes

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: A thin sample of Zr-2.5Nb was exposed to 1×10⁻³ Pa of D₂O vapor at 380°C for 360 h to determine the rate of permeation into the bulk alloy
conditions: 1×10⁻³ Pa D₂O vapor at 380°C for 360 h

extra_properties.deuterium_detection: practically no deuterium detected by DSC

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Samples of Zr-2.5Nb exposed to a gaseous environment consisting of predominantly deuterium gas (10⁻³ Pa) with only 10⁻⁵ Pa D₂O at 300°C for 48 h
conditions: 10⁻³ Pa D₂ + 10⁻⁵ Pa D₂O at 300°C for 48 h

extra_properties.deuterium_concentration: lower at surface and within oxide

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: samples were exposed to the same gaseous environment at 380°C for 330 h, a significant uptake by the bulk alloy was observed
conditions: 10⁻³ Pa D₂ + 10⁻⁵ Pa D₂O at 380°C for 330 h

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Deuterium depth profiles for prefilmed Zr-2.5Nb samples exposed to D₂O and D₂ at 380°C for up to 360°C

extra_properties.deuterium_concentration_distribution: low concentration near interface and in bulk alloy
extra_properties.deuterium_peaks: may represent hydrides formed upon cooling

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: High deuterium contents at the interface in Figs. 4 and 5 imply that local regions with extremely thin oxides are present...deuterum uptake is relatively low $( < 5 \%$ shown in Fig. 7 for the zirconium-niobium alloy exposed here)
conditions: out-reactor: D₂:D₂O ratio 250 at 380°C; in-reactor: D₂:D₂O ratio ~0.5; aqueous exposures at ~300°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: in the case of Fig. 5b for the 12 years exposure in-reactor, deuterium may permeate through the oxide to the interface and may react directly with the metal at local regions providing high uptake rates

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: out-reactor exposures to predominantly deuterium gas at high temperatures (D₂:D₂O ratio of 250 and 380°C)...the oxide-metal interface shifts towards the original oxide surface as a result of oxide dissolution
